dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: President Trump just signed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act into law.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: President Trump just signed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act into law.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed a bill on Wednesday that supports the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, after days of uncertainty surrounding his willingness to confront Beijing as he attempts to hammer out a trade deal with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, after days of uncertainty, right? He finally did it, um, even with the trade negotiations going on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, after days of uncertainty, right? He finally did it, um, even with the trade negotiations going on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until today it was unclear if Trump would sign the bill into law. The president has been relatively silent on Hong Kong as he negotiates a trade deal with Chinas President Xi Jinping.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The bill passed almost unanimously in Congress last week. It mandates sanctions for human rights violators in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The bill passed almost unanimously in Congress last week. It mandates sanctions for human rights violators in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bill, the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, was passed almost unanimously by both houses of Congress last week. It would mandate that the president impose sanctions against people found to be violating human rights in Hong Kong and require the State Department to give Congress annual reports assessing whether China has encroached on Hong Kongs autonomy or clamped down on civil liberties.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it requires the State Department to give annual reports on whether China is, like, encroaching on Hong Kong's autonomy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it requires the State Department to give annual reports on whether China is, like, encroaching on Hong Kong's autonomy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would mandate that the president impose sanctions against people found to be violating human rights in Hong Kong and require the State Department to give Congress annual reports assessing whether China has encroached on Hong Kongs autonomy or clamped down on civil liberties.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: In his statement, Trump said he signed it out of respect for President Xi and the people of Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: In his statement, Trump said he signed it out of respect for President Xi and the people of Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a statement announcing the signing, Trump said he signed the bill out of respect for President Xi, China and the people of Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a bit of a diplomatic tightrope, honestly. He's trying to balance trade talks with, uh, standing up for human rights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a bit of a diplomatic tightrope, honestly. He's trying to balance trade talks with, uh, standing up for human rights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Senator Marco Rubio called it a meaningful tool to deter Beijing's interference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Senator Marco Rubio called it a meaningful tool to deter Beijing's interference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. now has new and meaningful tools to deter further influence and interference from Beijing into Hong Kongs internal affairs, said Senator Marco Rubio, who introduced the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he mentioned the recent elections in Hong Kong—record turnout—so the timing feels significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he mentioned the recent elections in Hong Kong-record turnout-so the timing feels significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following last weekends historic elections in Hong Kong that included record turnout, this new law could not be more timely in showing strong U.S. support for Hong Kongers long-cherished freedoms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But until today, nobody was sure if Trump would actually go through with it. He'd been pretty quiet on Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But until today, nobody was sure if Trump would actually go through with it. He'd been pretty quiet on Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until today it was unclear if Trump would sign the bill into law. The president has been relatively silent on Hong Kong as he negotiates a trade deal with Chinas President Xi Jinping.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, he said on Fox and Friends that he has to stand with Hong Kong but also with Xi. Tough spot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, he said on Fox and Friends that he has to stand with Hong Kong but also with Xi. Tough spot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview on Fox and Friends last week, Trump said, We have to stand with Hong Kong, but Im also standing with President Xi, when asked if he would sign the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The protests started over an extradition bill but have grown into something much bigger against Beijing's control.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The protests started over an extradition bill but have grown into something much bigger against Beijing's control.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pro-democracy protests erupted in the semiautonomous region of Hong Kong months ago over a bill that would extradite those accused of committing a crime in Hong Kong to mainland China. While the bill has been withdrawn from consideration, the protests have become a larger movement against Beijings control over the city, sometimes devolving into violent clashes between protesters and police officers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And even though that bill was withdrawn, the movement's still going, sometimes turning violent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even though that bill was withdrawn, the movement's still going, sometimes turning violent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the bill has been withdrawn from consideration, the protests have become a larger movement against Beijings control over the city, sometimes devolving into violent clashes between protesters and police officers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So this U.S. law adds a new layer of pressure at a really delicate moment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this U.S. law adds a new layer of pressure at a really delicate moment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Now we wait to see how China responds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Now we wait to see how China responds.

artist_script:
Recording from Washington D.C., Thursday evening.
HostA: President Trump just signed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act into law.
HostB: Yeah, after days of uncertainty, right? He finally did it, um, even with the trade negotiations going on.
HostA: The bill passed almost unanimously in Congress last week. It mandates sanctions for human rights violators in Hong Kong.
HostB: And it requires the State Department to give annual reports on whether China is, like, encroaching on Hong Kong's autonomy.
HostA: In his statement, Trump said he signed it out of respect for President Xi and the people of Hong Kong.
HostB: Which is a bit of a diplomatic tightrope, honestly. He’s trying to balance trade talks with, uh, standing up for human rights.
HostA: Senator Marco Rubio called it a meaningful tool to deter Beijing’s interference.
HostB: And he mentioned the recent elections in Hong Kong—record turnout—so the timing feels significant.
HostA: But until today, nobody was sure if Trump would actually go through with it. He’d been pretty quiet on Hong Kong.
HostB: Right, he said on Fox and Friends that he has to stand with Hong Kong but also with Xi. Tough spot.
HostA: The protests started over an extradition bill but have grown into something much bigger against Beijing’s control.
HostB: And even though that bill was withdrawn, the movement’s still going, sometimes turning violent.
HostA: So this U.S. law adds a new layer of pressure at a really delicate moment.
HostB: Exactly. Now we wait to see how China responds.
